author: badpauly
body:
This is a list of the top 20 companies that experienced the largest change in insider shares in the last seven (7) days.
The SEC defines an insider as any officer, director or 10% shareholder. It is not illegal for these people to buy or sell their own shares.
In fact, since most of them get paid in stock options, it is expected. However, it is illegal for them to trade on inside information
that has not been made public. So for example if there are drug trial results that are bad and not public,
insiders cannot dump shares. That said, many people have observed that insiders - in general - seem to have a good
track record at timing their purchases.  All trades that are marked as part of a 10b5 plan are excluded from this report.

## Largest Insider Buying (Last 7 Days)
Company|Count|Shares Changed|Avg. Price|Value Change
--------|-----:|-----:|-----:|--------:

author: Lovegaming544
body: TYL all money in kenya is being stolen by corrupt government officials

author: AlmostAsianJim
body:
There's not much to talk about for $CLBT, it will need to perform at earnings now. I'm up to over 80k warrants and continuing to add. As long as peers ($TYL, $AXON, $MAGT.TO) do well as a group, I don't have issues with continuing to accumulate $CLBT.   
  
I think the biggest challenge here is that there's not enough public float for any institution to open a position in size; PIPE isn't selling, SUN isn't selling, IGP isn't selling, cost to borrow has been consistently high since merger close, etc... And there's no public support since it's not an exciting stock. All to these combined result in repeated red days with really low volume. We will have to play the patient game.  
  
In the meantime, I've diverted my attention over to Gogoro and Playboy. lol

author: AlmostAsianJim
body:
Quick stats:  
- Trading at 5x forward revenue multiple  
- 29x forward Adj EBITDA multiple
- Cash generative    
- SaaS with a strong Rule of 40  
- Fair value compared to peers ($TYL, $AXON, $MAGT.TO) is around $15/shr  
  
Having said all that, it's not uniquely the only de-spac that trades at a massive discount compared to peers. You just kind of have to pick a horse and stick with it for the long haul if you're picking a kicked-down despac.

author: ankole_watusi
body:
The idea that one company will own AR/VR is of course ridiculous.

While it’s cool you can converse in a virtual space with some uncanny creepy experience that simulates being in the same space, that will largely continue to be a novelty outside of games.

There are lots of practical applications in business - especially in warehousing, manufacturing, distribution. And FB is not going to be anyone’s go to.

One company to watch closely is Zebra.

author: CCChristopherson
body: I own ZBRA which was up 8% after earnings beat yesterday. I like the stock so I didn’t want to sell but I thought it would come back to earth today (currently down 4%).  I doubt I’ll do this but curious if others have - Does anyone ever do covered calls or puts on an earnings pump on a stock they own? Seems like the majority of time stocks lose some of their post-earnings gains

author: EngineeriusMaximus
body: I was thinking that synthetic positions are cheap leverage. For example, a 2023 SPY synthetic (one short ATM put, one long ATM call) currently requires \~$14,700 in collateral and 0 cash, and a SPY ZEBRA requires $12000 in cash. Both of these represent $46,000 worth of SPY, so you are getting 3x+ leverage. You can get even lower collateral requirements if you go a little OTM on both the put and call, e.g. short 430 put and long 485 call, with collateral of just over $10k. These make sense to hold for long periods as leveraged SPY plays, right?

author: analnapalm
body: I don't have anything significant on my short term radar and am mostly cash as I feel the market is a little overheated at the moment.  Long term, it's difficult to imagine not seeing QQQ, NVDA, & AAPL somewhere in my portfolio.  Perhaps also TGT and ZBRA.

author: GimmeAllDaTendiesNow
body:
Purchasing shares to cover a short position can work, but it can also work against you. It's a very capital-intensive way to cover the position in any case. I've done it before both successful and not. A more capital-efficient way of doing this is cover the short with a deep ITM long option or a ZEBRA. I prefer ZEBRAs, especially long-dated.

You are always going to get a lot of sanctimonious knee-jerk responses about selling calls from people who have no idea what they are talking about. As someone who has sold naked calls for years, it's risky and it's a lot harder to make money than by put-selling. There's also a lot of value to balanced delta in my opinion. 

Most of the time lately they are either challenged or at an unrealized loss, but rarely ITM, depending on your entry delta. You usually get a month or two out of the year where they are the only thing that pays. It's easy to not be stupid about it. Don't trade meme stocks and don't sell 400 naked puts on a $20K account. The last few months have been rough, because a lot of stuff is up significantly more than volatility had priced in. Vol is just way under priced right now. I have strangles on MSFT, CVS, WMT and XRT that have all blown way past my short call strike. I'm inverted on all of them. At the same time, a lot of stuff has tanked and gone way past my short put strikes.

author: professor__doom
body:
The company that's going to figure out is Zebra or ABB or someone else in that space, because the only application I can possibly see for AR is industrial.

I just can't fathom consumers imposing that on themselves willingly.

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body:
About 2 years and about 30% percent a year. Started with 190k in a Schwab MMF, went to stocks (shares only) last March and am up to 348k. I’m about 90 different positions, I realize I have too many small positions. My large positions have done very well though. NVDA, AVGO, TER, TTD, MA, BRKB, C, BAC, SHOP, TSLA, ZBRA, GOOG, AAPL are my large blue chip holdings.

Edit : I realize I’ve lucked out with timing and won’t get 30% a year every year but I’m thankful for the portfolio I’ve managed to put together and believe it could outperform long term or get dumpster fucked who knows.

author: releb
body: I usually sell options but there are some good long theta plays. However these usually require more capital than a plain long call. The best one IMO is the stock replacement leap. Basically buy a near 100 delta deep itm call. Best to use when IV is low. Another one is a short atm put to buy a long atm call and the zebra which is long two itm calls versus 1 short atm call. Each strategy aims for a 100 delta with as little theta as possible.

author: Awkward-Painter-2024
body:
He probably had a tet-a-tet with Melvin... realized there are billions more than can be made by shorting this shit. (This can easily be done through a hedge fund.) And frankly, the only ones who are going to get hit are the institutional investors who were forced to buy this shit through indexing... My guess he has a shell company in South Africa or something. He'll create the first fully autocratic corporate state over there and live out the rest of his days in a diamond mine feasting on zebra meat! 

Also, that lawsuit, he's going to lose it. Weird to root for another corporate overload, but what are you going to do. It's the times we're living in! It's going to set a precedent that will reverberate through social media. It's been fun!!!

author: coconubs94

author: geauxtigers10
body: Zebra cakes

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body: Yea I’m not saying the picks are always trash. My brother has stock advisors account and I use it sometimes. I bought CRWD, SHOP, TTD, SQ, ODFL, CRTO, ZBRA and a few others based on their picks and doubled up or more on most of them “over 3-5 years lol”. Don’t take their picks as gospel is all I’m saying bc they’re wrong quite a bit too (PINS, SAM, SKLZ and ZNGA come to mind for recent fuck ups). Sure in 5 years all these stocks will be up but the time value of money will still likely make them poor investments in hindsight.

author: CCChristopherson
body: I own ZBRA which was up 8% after earnings beat yesterday. I like the stock so I didn’t want to sell but I thought it would come back to earth today (currently down 4%).  I doubt I’ll do this but curious if others have - Does anyone ever do covered calls or puts on an earnings pump on a stock they own? Seems like the majority of time stocks lose some of their post-earnings gains

author: EngineeriusMaximus
body: I was thinking that synthetic positions are cheap leverage. For example, a 2023 SPY synthetic (one short ATM put, one long ATM call) currently requires \~$14,700 in collateral and 0 cash, and a SPY ZEBRA requires $12000 in cash. Both of these represent $46,000 worth of SPY, so you are getting 3x+ leverage. You can get even lower collateral requirements if you go a little OTM on both the put and call, e.g. short 430 put and long 485 call, with collateral of just over $10k. These make sense to hold for long periods as leveraged SPY plays, right?

author: analnapalm
body: I don't have anything significant on my short term radar and am mostly cash as I feel the market is a little overheated at the moment.  Long term, it's difficult to imagine not seeing QQQ, NVDA, & AAPL somewhere in my portfolio.  Perhaps also TGT and ZBRA.

author: GimmeAllDaTendiesNow
body:
Purchasing shares to cover a short position can work, but it can also work against you. It's a very capital-intensive way to cover the position in any case. I've done it before both successful and not. A more capital-efficient way of doing this is cover the short with a deep ITM long option or a ZEBRA. I prefer ZEBRAs, especially long-dated.

You are always going to get a lot of sanctimonious knee-jerk responses about selling calls from people who have no idea what they are talking about. As someone who has sold naked calls for years, it's risky and it's a lot harder to make money than by put-selling. There's also a lot of value to balanced delta in my opinion. 

Most of the time lately they are either challenged or at an unrealized loss, but rarely ITM, depending on your entry delta. You usually get a month or two out of the year where they are the only thing that pays. It's easy to not be stupid about it. Don't trade meme stocks and don't sell 400 naked puts on a $20K account. The last few months have been rough, because a lot of stuff is up significantly more than volatility had priced in. Vol is just way under priced right now. I have strangles on MSFT, CVS, WMT and XRT that have all blown way past my short call strike. I'm inverted on all of them. At the same time, a lot of stuff has tanked and gone way past my short put strikes.

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body:
About 2 years and about 30% percent a year. Started with 190k in a Schwab MMF, went to stocks (shares only) last March and am up to 348k. I’m about 90 different positions, I realize I have too many small positions. My large positions have done very well though. NVDA, AVGO, TER, TTD, MA, BRKB, C, BAC, SHOP, TSLA, ZBRA, GOOG, AAPL are my large blue chip holdings.

Edit : I realize I’ve lucked out with timing and won’t get 30% a year every year but I’m thankful for the portfolio I’ve managed to put together and believe it could outperform long term or get dumpster fucked who knows.
